items.author: Reuters

items.title: US business equipment borrowings down more than 4% y/y in November, ELFA says
items.author: Reuters
items.summary:
- In November, U.S. companies borrowed 4.4% less for equipment investments year over year, with new financing totaling $10.3 billion (seasonally adjusted).
- Activity declined across banks, captives, and independents: banks $4.9B (-1%), captives $2.9B (-9.3%), independents $1.9B (-12.9%).
- ELFA notes healthy financial conditions and says a 75 basis-point cut in the federal funds rate in 2025 could bolster equipment-demand momentum; Confidence Index held at 58.3.

items.title: Driverless future gains momentum with global robotaxi deployments
items.author: Reuters
items.summary:
- Global robotaxi testing and partnerships span Uber/Lyft, Baidu Apollo Go, WeRide, Pony.ai, Zoox, Waymo, Tesla, Mercedes-Benz, Grab and others, with 2025–2026 trials.
- Driverless pilots and limited services are planned in Austin, London, San Francisco, Guangzhou, Singapore, Abu Dhabi, Zurich and more as permits expand.
- The pace signals broad global momentum with fleet ops, safety monitoring and charging to enable commercial autonomous ride-hailing.

items.title: HTC bets its open AI strategy to drive smartglasses sales
items.author: Wen-Yee Lee
items.summary: - HTC's VIVE Eagle AI glasses run on an open platform that supports multiple AI models (Gemini, OpenAI), enabling model switching. - The HK$3,988 device debuted in Hong Kong and will roll out to Japan and Southeast Asia in Q1 2026, with Europe/US later in 2026. - HTC emphasizes Asia-first design, cautious entry into China due to data rules, and that user data is not used to train its AI models, touting privacy as a differentiator.

items.title: South African rand gains as precious metals prices jump
items.author: Reuters
items.summary: - The rand rose about 0.4% to around 16.70 per dollar by 0744 GMT as precious metals surged.\n- Johannesburg's Top-40 index rose about 1.3% while gold hit a record and platinum climbed to its highest in more than 17 years.\n- Analysts warned the rand could test 16.70 again amid the metals rally, with year-to-date gains above 12%.

items.author: Reuters

items.title: China hits EU dairy products with provisional duties
items.author: Reuters
items.summary:
- China imposes provisional anti-subsidy duties on EU dairy imports (milk and cheese such as Roquefort) at 21.9%–42.7%, with most firms around 30%. 
- About 60 firms, including Arla Foods, face rates of roughly 28.6%–29.7%; some pay 21.9%–42.7% if not participating; duties start collection soon. 
- Moves follow a concluded probe and are seen as retaliation for EU EV tariffs; final ruling could revise duties as China tackles a milk glut.

items.title: Italy regulator fines Apple $115 million for alleged App Store privacy violations
items.author: Reuters
items.summary:
- Italy's AGCM fined Apple and two divisions about €98.6 million for abusing a dominant position in the App Store, citing “absolute dominance” over third-party developers.
- The probe found Apple imposed a more restrictive privacy policy from April 2021 and forced duplicate consent requests for data collection and advertising linking via the ATT prompt.
- Apple defends ATT as protecting user privacy and plans to appeal; AGCM deemed terms unilateral, detrimental to partners, and not compliant with privacy rules.

items.title: Elon Musk becomes first person worth $700 billion following pay package ruling
items.author: Reuters
items.summary:
- Musk's net worth surges to about $749 billion after the Delaware Supreme Court reinstated Tesla stock options worth $139 billion and the 2018 $56 billion pay package.
- The ruling overturns a 2024 decision, reviving the high-value package and fueling SpaceX IPO chatter and a historic $1 trillion Tesla pay plan approved in November.
- Reuters notes market reactions and comparisons to Google's Larry Page, highlighting unprecedented wealth concentration and attention on mega payouts.

items.title: Stellantis CEO says investments at risk in Europe after EU auto package
items.author: Reuters
items.summary:
- EU auto-package would drop the 2035 ban on new combustion cars; Filosa says the measures could curb investments and undermine growth and a resilient European supply chain.
- Stellantis says the proposals fail to address core challenges, notably a roadmap for light commercial vehicles and more flexibility on 2030 passenger-car targets, with automakers divided.
- Filosa warned there are no urgent steps to restore growth and urged clearer, committed policy actions to sustain investment in Europe.
